After updating IDs: 

  • Restart cds watch 
  • Refresh the List Report 
  • Click a row to navigate to the Object Page 

Navigation should now work without errors. 

 

3. Resolving label, Facts and Field Group Issues 

 

While building the application, one of the simplest issues ended up taking the most time. The table columns and the Object Page labels were still showing in lower case and non of the Facets and FieldGroup annotation getting applied, even after adding annotations. It looked like a small thing, but it completely stopped the flow and took far longer to debug than expected. 

As shown below, the labels in the List Report and the Object Page simply refused to update: 

At first, the problem did not make sense. The annotations were correct, the service was running, and the UI preview was refreshing. But the labels stayed exactly the same. Eventually, the root cause turned out to be something very easy to overlook: the application generator had created an annotation file under the app folder, and that file was overriding the behavior. Since CDS annotations inside the UI module are not compiled by CAP, the UI was never getting the updated metadata. 

 

CDS-based annotations inside the app folder are not included in the service metadata, so the UI will never pick them up. 
Because of this, the generated file should be deleted or renamed to avoid confusion. 

 

There are two ways to manage annotations for the application: 

Option A (Recommended): Use server-side CDS annotations 

Move or copy all annotation blocks into: srv/annotations.cds 

CAP will compile these annotations and expose them in the OData $metadata. 
Fiori Elements reads its UI behavior from service metadata, so this is the cleanest and most reliable approach. 
This is the best practice for CAP-first projects. 

Option B: Keep UI-side annotation file and reference it from the UI 

If you prefer to keep the generator-created file under: app/productfe/annotations/ 

then the content must be translated into an OData annotation XML/JSON file and referenced directly in manifest.json as an annotation source. 
This keeps the annotations on the UI side only, and works independently of CAP metadata. 

This approach is possible, but it requires extra steps and is harder to maintain. It is usually not recommended when building applications with CAP, because UI annotations do not flow through the OData service metadata. 

 

Updated UI on deleting the annotation file following Option A 
 

Object Page Changes 

Updated Code Structure

using my.products as prod from '../db/schema'; 

// Element Level Labels 
annotate prod.Products with { 
    name        @title: 'Product Name'; 
    description @title: 'Product Description'; 
    category    @title: 'Category'; 
    price       @title: 'Price'; 
    stock       @title: 'Stock Available'; 
    releaseDate @title: 'Release Date'; 
    isAvailable @title: 'Available'; 
};

annotate prod.Products with @( 
    UI               : { 
        HeaderInfo     : { 
            TypeName      : 'Product', 
            TypeNamePlural: 'Products', 
            Title         : {Value: name} 
        }, 

        SelectionFields: [ 
            name, 
            category 
        ], 

        LineItem: [ 
            { Value: name }, 
            { Value: category }, 
            { Value: price }, 
            { Value: stock }, 
            { Value: isAvailable } 
        ], 

        Identification : [ 
            {Value: name}, 
            {Value: description}, 
            {Value: category} 
        ], 

        Facets: [ 
            { 
                $Type: 'UI.ReferenceFacet', 
                Label: 'Product Details', 
                Target: '@UI.Identification' 
            }, 
            {
                $Type: 'UI.ReferenceFacet', 
                Label: 'Stock Information', 
                Target: '@UI.FieldGroup#Stock'
            }
        ],
        FieldGroup #Stock: {
            Data: [
                { Value: stock },
                { Value: isAvailable }
            ] 
        },
    }
);

After applying this file and refreshing the preview, the Object Page should now have: 

  • Friendly labels 
  • A clean header 
  • Product details section 
  • Stock section 
  • Proper grouping of fields 

7. Summary 

At this stage, the Object Page now feels like a proper application screen rather than a raw auto-generated view. The fields have meaningful labels, the content is organized into sections, and navigation works without errors. These elements provide the structure needed for the next phase of enhancements as the application grows.

entry.title: From Zero to Fiori: Building SAP Apps with AI Agents (And Why I Use Markdown Files Instead of MCP)
entry.content:
45 minutes.

That's how long it took to build a Customer Feedback & Complaint Management system on SAP BTP: 11 backend entities, 4 Fiori apps with 2,500+ lines of UI annotations, semantic coloring, and working navigation.

It's not ready to ship project - but solid base to start devloping.

I didn't write the code. I orchestrated 5 specialized AI agents while focusing on architecture decisions and error correction. The agents are Markdown files with specific instructions, not an MCP server, not a fine-tuned model.

This choice surprises people. Let me explain why it works.

The agent Markdown files are in my GitHub repository: https://github.com/michal-majer/sap-cap-fiori-ai-agents


The Real Problem: Generic AI Fails at SAP

Ask ChatGPT or Claude to "build a Fiori app" and watch it fail. The model will write outdated syntax, hallucinate file structures instead of using generators, skip authorization patterns, and forget annotations that make Fiori actually usable.

The reason is simple: SAP CAP and Fiori Elements have specific conventions that aren't well-represented in public training data. The models know JavaScript and OData in general, but they don't know that @ui.LineItem annotations need specific ordering, or that Fiori generators create manifest.json files you shouldn't edit manually.

Generic prompts produce generic (broken) code.

Why Markdown Agents Instead of MCP?

Model Context Protocol is powerful. It lets AI tools call external services, access databases, and execute actions. So why am I using plain text files?

Three reasons:

1. Portability across AI interfaces

My Markdown agents work in Claude, in Cursor, in Windsurf, in any AI tool that accepts context files. When I switch tools (which happens often during experimentation), my agents come with me. No reconfiguration, no server setup.

2. Transparency and version control

Every instruction my agent follows is visible in a .md file I can read, edit, and commit to Git. When the AI makes a mistake, I can trace it back to which rule was missing or unclear. With MCP, the logic lives in server code. That's fine for stable integrations, but during iteration I need to see exactly what the AI "knows."

3. Lower barrier to iteration

Changing agent behavior means editing text. I can do it mid-session. "Add a rule: always use @CDS.localized for text fields" takes 10 seconds. Building this into an MCP server would require deployment cycles.

MCP makes sense for production integrations where you need real-time data access or external API calls. For development workflows where the AI manipulates local files, Markdown agents are faster to iterate.

The Agent Architecture

Five Markdown files, each with a specific role:

Full Stack Orchestrator breaks requirements into tasks and asks clarifying questions before any code gets written. It enforces the planning phase that developers usually skip.

SAP CAP Developer handles schema.cds and service.cds. It knows authorization patterns, associations, and generates mock data automatically.

SAP Fiori Designer decides which floorplans fit the use case. List Report for the Support Workbench, Object Page for complaint details, Worklist for the Customer Portal.

SAP Fiori Scaffolder has one strict rule: never create Fiori file structures manually. It uses Yeoman generators because manually written manifest.json files always have subtle bugs.

Fiori Elements Developer adds UI annotations: @UI.LineItem, @UI.SelectionField, @UI.FieldGroup, and criticality coloring. This is where raw IDs become human-readabledropdowns.

The Exact Prompts I Used

Here's the actual conversation flow from my session:

Initial prompt to Orchestrator:

 
Develop a SAP CAP application for managing customer feedback and complaints. The application should allow customers to submit feedback, enable support staff to categorize, assign, and resolve issues, and provide reporting on trends and recurring problems. Ensure a clean data model, CRUD services, and REST/OData endpoints for integration. @./ai/sap-full-stack-orchestrator

Phase 1: Requirements gathering

The Orchestrator didn't write any code. Instead, it asked clarifying questions:

  • What user roles do we need? → Customer, Support Staff, Manager, Admin
  • What is the lifecycle of a complaint? → Submit → Categorize → Assign → Resolve, with reopen capability
  • Do customers have BTP accounts? → Yes, managed internally
  • Multi-language support? → English only, single-tenant

After I answered, the Orchestrator produced a detailed implementation plan covering all phases. I reviewed it, asked for adjustments, and approved.

Phase 2-6: Backend development

The CAP Developer agent took over. It generated:

  • db/schema.cds with 11 entities
  • 8 CSV files with seed data
  • 5 service definitions (customer, support, manager, admin, analytics)
  • Service handlers with business logic
  • Authorization rules in access-control.cds

I ran cds watch after each major step. When the Customers endpoint returned 403, I pasted the error. The agent found the missing authorization scope and fixed it.

Phase 7: Frontend scaffolding

This is where the AI initially went off track:

 
Stop. Please use generator.
Please follow guide in @sap-fiori-scaffolder.md and use fiori-elements-writer

The AI had tried to create Fiori folder structures manually. After my correction, it installed @sap-ux/fiori-elements-writer and generated all 4 apps using the official SAP tooling. The resulting manifest.json files were correctly configured for deployment.

Phase 8: UI annotations

 
Let's go to the next phase, please create perfect fiori application. @.ai/sap-fiori-elements-developer.md

The Fiori Elements Developer agent scanned all OData services and generated 2,500+ lines of annotations: labels, value helps, criticality coloring, header facets, conditional actions, and organized object pages.

Error correction pattern:

I have some errors in admin-console application.RoutingServiceFactory-dbg.js:61 Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'getMetaModel')

The AI immediately identified the issue: manifest.json had a named model "Complaints" instead of the default unnamed model "". Fixed in under a minute.

Triggering annotation phase:

Let's go to the next phase, please create perfect fiori application. @.ai/sap-fiori-elements-developer.md

What Got Generated

 

  • 11 database entities (Customers, Complaints, Categories, Priorities, Statuses, StatusTransitions, Comments, Attachments, StatusHistory, SupportStaff, ComplaintAnalytics)
  • 5 OData services with role-based access
  • 4 Fiori Elements apps
  • 2,500+ lines of UI annotations
  • 8 CSV files with seed data
  • 6 mocked users for testing

The Data Model
The CAP Developer agent generated a clean domain model following CAP conventions:

amespace customer.complaints;

using { managed, cuid, User, Country } from '@sap/cds/common';

/**
 * CUSTOMERS
 * Users who submit and track feedback/complaints
 */
entity Customers : cuid, managed {
  customerNumber   : String(20);                 // Auto-generated (e.g., CUST-20251207-00001)
  firstName        : String(100) @mandatory;
  lastName         : String(100) @mandatory;
  email            : String(256) @mandatory;     // BTP account email
  phone            : String(50);
  company          : String(200);

  // BTP Integration
  btpUserId        : String(256) @mandatory;     // BTP user ID for authentication
  isActive         : Boolean default true;

  // Relationships
  complaints       : Composition of many Complaints on complaints.customer = $self;
}

/**
 * COMPLAINTS
 * Core entity for customer feedback and complaints
 */
entity Complaints : cuid, managed {
  complaintNumber  : String(30) not null;        // Auto-generated (e.g., CMP-20251207-00001)

  // Basic Information
  title            : String(200) @mandatory;
  description      : String(5000) @mandatory @UI.MultiLineText;

  // Classification
  category         : Association to Categories @mandatory;
  priority         : Association to Priorities @mandatory;
  status           : Association to Statuses @mandatory;

  // Assignment
  customer         : Association to Customers @mandatory;
  assignedTo       : Association to SupportStaff;
  assignedBy       : Association to SupportStaff;  // Manager who assigned
  assignedAt       : DateTime;

  // Dates
  submittedDate    : DateTime @mandatory @cds.on.insert: $now;
  targetDate       : Date;                        // Expected resolution date
  resolvedDate     : DateTime;
  closedDate       : DateTime;
  reopenedDate     : DateTime;

  // Resolution
  resolutionNotes  : String(5000) @UI.MultiLineText;
  rootCause        : String(1000);
  correctiveAction : String(1000);

  // Metrics (virtual fields calculated in handlers)
  virtual daysOpen        : Integer;
  virtual isOverdue       : Boolean;
  virtual statusCriticality: Integer;
  virtual priorityCriticality: Integer;

  // Relationships
  comments         : Composition of many Comments on comments.complaint = $self;
  attachments      : Composition of many Attachments on attachments.complaint = $self;
  history          : Composition of many StatusHistory on history.complaint = $self;
}

/**
 * CATEGORIES
 * Hierarchical categorization system
 */
entity Categories : cuid {
  code             : String(20) not null;
  name             : String(100) not null;
  description      : String(500);

  // Hierarchy support
  parent           : Association to Categories;
  children         : Composition of many Categories on children.parent = $self;

  // Routing
  defaultPriority  : Association to Priorities;
  autoAssignTo     : Association to SupportStaff;  // Auto-assign to specific staff

  isActive         : Boolean default true;
  sortOrder        : Integer default 0;
}

/**
 * PRIORITIES
 * Priority levels for complaints
 */
entity Priorities : cuid {
  code             : String(20) not null;
  name             : String(100) not null;
  description      : String(500);

  // SLA Configuration
  slaHours         : Integer;                     // Target resolution time in hours
  escalateAfterHours: Integer;                    // Auto-escalate if not resolved

  // Display
  criticality      : Integer default 0;           // 0=Grey, 1=Red, 2=Orange, 3=Green
  sortOrder        : Integer default 0;
  isActive         : Boolean default true;
}

/**
 * STATUSES
 * Workflow states for complaints
 */
entity Statuses : cuid {
  code             : String(20) not null;
  name             : String(100) not null;
  description      : String(500);

  // Workflow Control
  isInitialStatus  : Boolean default false;       // New complaints start here
  isFinalStatus    : Boolean default false;       // Terminal states
  canReopen        : Boolean default false;       // Can reopen from this status

  // Valid transitions
  allowedTransitions: Association to many StatusTransitions on allowedTransitions.fromStatus = $self;

  // Display
  criticality      : Integer default 0;
  sortOrder        : Integer default 0;
  isActive         : Boolean default true;
}

/**
 * STATUS TRANSITIONS
 * Allowed state transitions
 */
entity StatusTransitions : cuid {
  fromStatus       : Association to Statuses @mandatory;
  toStatus         : Association to Statuses @mandatory;
  requiredRole     : String(50);                  // Role required for transition
  requiresComment  : Boolean default false;
  isActive         : Boolean default true;
}

/**
 * COMMENTS
 * Timeline of updates and communications
 */
entity Comments : cuid, managed {
  complaint        : Association to Complaints @mandatory;
  commentText      : String(5000) @mandatory @UI.MultiLineText;

  // Categorization
  commentType      : String(50) default 'UPDATE'; // UPDATE, INTERNAL, CUSTOMER, SYSTEM
  isInternal       : Boolean default false;       // Hide from customer
  isSystemGenerated: Boolean default false;       // Auto-generated

  // User info captured at creation time
  authorName       : String(200);
  authorRole       : String(50);
}

/**
 * ATTACHMENTS
 * File attachments for complaints
 */
entity Attachments : cuid, managed {
  complaint        : Association to Complaints @mandatory;

  @Core.MediaType: mediaType
  @Core.ContentDisposition.Filename: filename
  content          : LargeBinary;

  @Core.IsMediaType
  mediaType        : String;
  filename         : String(256);
  fileSize         : Integer;
  description      : String(500);
}

/**
 * STATUS HISTORY
 * Audit trail of status changes
 */
entity StatusHistory : cuid {
  complaint        : Association to Complaints @mandatory;
  fromStatus       : Association to Statuses;
  toStatus         : Association to Statuses @mandatory;
  changedAt        : DateTime @mandatory @cds.on.insert: $now;
  changedBy        : String(256);                 // BTP user ID
  changedByName    : String(200);
  reason           : String(1000);
}

/**
 * SUPPORT STAFF
 * Internal users handling complaints
 */
entity SupportStaff : cuid, managed {
  staffNumber      : String(20);
  firstName        : String(100) @mandatory;
  lastName         : String(100) @mandatory;
  email            : String(256) @mandatory;
  phone            : String(50);

  // BTP Integration
  btpUserId        : String(256) @mandatory;

  // Role & Capacity
  role             : String(50) @mandatory;       // SUPPORT, MANAGER, ADMIN
  department       : String(100);
  isActive         : Boolean default true;
  maxConcurrentCases: Integer default 20;

  // Specialization
  specializations  : Association to many Categories on specializations.autoAssignTo = $self;

  // Metrics
  virtual currentCaseload: Integer;
  virtual avgResolutionDays: Decimal(5,2);
}

/**
 * ANALYTICS VIEWS
 * Pre-aggregated data for reporting
 */
@readonly
entity ComplaintAnalytics as projection on Complaints {
  key ID,
  complaintNumber,
  category.code as categoryCode,
  category.name as categoryName,
  priority.code as priorityCode,
  priority.name as priorityName,
  status.code as statusCode,
  status.name as statusName,
  assignedTo.ID as assignedToID,
  assignedTo.firstName || ' ' || assignedTo.lastName as assignedToName : String(200),
  submittedDate,
  resolvedDate,
  closedDate,
  daysOpen,
  isOverdue
};

Preview of one of the application after using Fiori Elements Developer agent:

List PageObject Page

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


What I Learned

Planning time isn't wasted time. The Orchestrator agent spent 5 minutes asking about user roles, complaint lifecycles, and entity relationships before writing any code. Skipping this produces apps that need restructuring later.

Explicit rules beat implicit knowledge. I added "always generate mock CSV data" to the CAP Developer agent after sessions where the AI forgot. Now it never forgets. Every bug becomes a rule.

The AI doesn't know what it doesn't know. It won't tell you it's uncertain about Fiori annotation syntax. It will confidently write something wrong. Your job is recognizing when output looks suspicious and asking for verification or alternatives.

Human oversight scales the bottleneck, doesn't remove it. You still need to understand CAP and Fiori to review what the agents produce. The speedup comes from not typing boilerplate, not from removing the need for expertise.

Correction prompts are shorter than initial prompts. Once the AI has context, you can say "fix authorization for admin" instead of explaining the entire access control model. The AI remembers what it built.

Try It Yourself

The agent Markdown files are in my GitHub repository: https://github.com/michal-majer/sap-cap-fiori-ai-agents

Prerequisites:

  • Visual Studio Code with an AI extension that supports file context (Claude Dev, Cursor, or similar)
  • Choose between Claude Opus 4.5 / Sonnet 4.5 or Gemini Pro 3
  • Node.js
  • Basic familiarity with SAP CAP (you need to recognize when output is wrong)

Drop the .md files in your project root, start a session, and give the Orchestrator a business requirement. Watch how it decomposes the task before coding begins.

Video walkthrough: youtube.com

What should I build agents for next?
What errors did you encounter?
Which agent was most useful?

Drop a comment 🙂

entry.title: Issue Verifiable Credentials for the Swiss E-ID environment on the SAP Business Technology Platform
entry.content:
Setting Up the swiyu Generic Issuer on SAP BTP

Having your ID, drivers license, professional certification, insurance confirmation all on your phone can make your life easier. With the Swiss E-ID infrastructure, that’s possible. Both government bodies and non-government organizations (reads: companies or yourself) can use the trust infrastructure of the Swiss E-ID to issue their own certificates.

Building on our first blog post on verifying the Swiss E-ID, this article now explores the next step: how to issue your own digital credentials using the swiyu Generic Issuer. If you haven’t read the verification blog yet, we recommend starting there for background on the architecture and trust model.

In this post, we walk through how to deploy the swiyu Generic Issuer – the official reference implementation for issuing verifiable credentials – on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). This allows your business applications to create and deliver swiyu-compatible credentials (such as identity proofs, age confirmations, or membership cards) directly into users’ wallets. The result: a streamlined, secure, and privacy-preserving alternative to traditional ID checks or manual credentialing workflows.

Business Relevance

Many business processes require issuing credentials. For example, companies issuing digital certificates to new employees (like an employee ID), to customers (membership cards or warranties), credentials of certifications, or to minors (age-restriction certificates). This involved validating pictures of paper documents with tedious validation steps. With swiyu’s infrastructure, the Generic Issuer can create signed digital credentials that go straight into a user’s swiyu wallet; these credentials are cryptographically signed, ensuring they are tamper-proof and digitally verifiable by anyone, and crucially, empower the certificate holder to selectively decide exactly which information they share with the verifier. This streamlines workflows like HR onboarding, verification of certificates, KYC (know your customer, the identification of legal or natural persons in the financial industry), or age checks: issuing is done via trusted digital channels without disclosing extra data, since the user’s identity attributes never leave their device

Architecture

The swiyu Generic Issuer is a government-provided reference implementation bundling all the core functionality needed for credential issuance. It runs as your own server (for example on SAP BTP) with a backing database, and it interacts with the swiyu trust infrastructure. The issuer service uses a Decentralized Identifier (DID) registered in the swiyu Base Registry (holding its public keys) and is listed in the Trust Registry (for trust statements). When issuing a credential, the issuer talks to a user’s swiyu wallet via standard APIs, and to the swiyu Trust Registry to publish status updates (e.g. revocation). The holder’s wallet only releases attributes to the issuer with user consent. The overall system is illustrated below:

Figure 1: Basic architecture of the swiyu-issuer implementation on SAP BTP

 

Setting Up Your Own Issuer on SAP BTP

Prerequisites:

  • Cloud foundry space
  • PostgreSQL Entitlement
  • Registered application / business on the FOITTs platform (for details see here)

Now deploy the Generic Issuer service on SAP BTP:

  1. Provision Database: In the SAP BTP Cockpit (or CF CLI), create a PostgreSQL service instance in your space. Once provisioned, generate a service key to retrieve credentials (host, port, username, password) for your application.
  2. Prepare Environment Variables: On your local machine, create a manifest.yml for Cloud Foundry push and a .env file (or use cf set-env) defining the needed variables. (E.g. ISSUER_ID, EXTERNAL_URL, SWIYU_PARTNER_ID, etc.)
    1. Be aware that you specify the fields of your to-issue credential in the “issuer-metadata”.
  3. Status Registry Credentials: the SWIYU_STATUS_REGISTRY_* keys, tokens and URLs obtained from the API portal (customer key/secret, refresh token, OAuth token URL, status API URL).
  4. Verification Methods: the DID’s verification method identifiers for status and SD-JWT signing (from the DID log). For example, DID_STATUS_LIST_VERIFICATION_METHOD must match the DID assertion key used for the status list.
  1. Deploy the Issuer App: Set the Docker image for swiyu-issuer. (FOITT provides ready images on Docker Hub.) Use cf push with your manifest to deploy the issuer. After pushing, the issuer’s management API and Swagger UI will be available.
  2. Initialize Status List: Before issuing any credential, the issuer must initialize a status list slot. Call the issuer’s management API endpoint  – save this URL and ID for use when issuing credentials. This step creates the on-chain slot needed to track revocations.
  3. Access and Secure the API: You can explore the issuer’s endpoints using its built-in Swagger UI (e.g. at https://<your-app>/swagger-ui.html). All calls for creating offers and checking status can be tested here. For any management or production deployment, secure the API (e.g. via a fixed asymmetric key or OAuth2) to prevent unauthorized issuance. (Note: The default configuration is for experimentation; for production-grade security consult FOITT’s deployment guide.)
  4. Optional: Frontend Integration: For user convenience, you may build a simple front-end (e.g. a SAP UI5 or CAP service) that interacts with the issuer API. In a PoC we integrated JWT-based authentication with a UI5 app so end-users can easily trigger and view issuance. This is not strictly required, but can streamline the UX when customers interact with the issuance flow.

Issuing Credentials

With the issuer running and initialized, you can now issue credentials. The general flow is:

  • Your application triggers a credential offer: call the issuer’s POST /management/api/credentials endpoint with the credential data. This includes fields like credential_subject_data (e.g. name, birthdate) and the "status_lists" array containing the statusRegistryUrl from before.
  • The response will contain a management_id and an offer_deeplink URL. The latter is a QR-code deep link for the swiyu wallet. Render this (e.g. as a QR code in your web page). When the wallet scans it, the holder sees an issuance request (prompt to accept or decline).
  • Revocation/Suspension: Later, if needed (e.g. a credential should be cancelled or suspended), update its status via PATCH with credentialStatus=REVOKED or SUSPENDED. This updates the public status list so verifiers know the credential is no longer valid.

To illustrate: after issuing an offer, the terminal shows something like

{"management_id":"abc123", "offer_deeplink":"swiyu-issue://?client_id=..."}

You turn that deep link into a QR code and scan it with the swiyu wallet. The wallet then prompts the user to accept the new credential. Once accepted, the issuer marks it as ISSUED in the registry. The user’s device now holds a signed verifiable credential (e.g. their new digital e-ID).

Figure 2: Credential offer on the users swiyu-wallet

 

 

Conclusion

By following these steps, you will have your own swiyu Generic Issuer running on SAP BTP, registered as a valid issuer in the Swiss trust registry, and ready to issue QR-based e-ID credentials. In practice, this lets you integrate trusted digital credential issuance into any business process – from HR identity checks, to age verification in e‑commerce, to verification of certifications, to KYC/AML flows – without costly manual ID or document scans. All credential data remains cryptographically protected and on the user’s device, while your service simply asks the swiyu trust infrastructure to verify the issuer’s identity and handle revocations.

Next Steps: Be sure to, if you haven’t yet, check out our blog post on setting up and deploying the swiyu Generic Verifier on SAP BTP. Together, these components complete the swiyu ecosystem on SAP BTP, enabling fully digital, privacy-preserving identity and credential workflows.

entry.title: Prompt-Driven Development: Building Full-Stack SAP CAP Apps from User Stories
entry.content:
Introduction

  • What if you could translate a business requirement into a functional, full-stack application with a single prompt?
  • How much faster could you deliver value if the foundational code and project scaffolding were generated for you in seconds?

This is the new reality powered by SAP Build Code and its integrated AI copilot, Joule.

As a turn-key environment on the SAP Business Technology Platform, it unifies the entire development lifecycle, from coding to deployment.

This post demonstrates how to build a full-stack SAP CAP application directly from a user story, showcasing how

generative AI is fundamentally reshaping the developer experience.

 

Business Requirement

Build an SAP CAP application based on the requirements in the user story below:

User Story

As a contract administrator, I want to create and manage contracts and ‘parties involved’ information in the system,

so that I can effectively track and handle legal agreements and ‘parties involved’ interactions.

Contracts can cover a vast range of agreements, such as sales contracts, service agreements and employment contracts.

Party involved: A ‘party involved’ is an individual, organization, or entity that purchases goods, products, or services from another party,

typically a business or seller.

Common attributes of a contract might include:

  1. Contract ID: A unique identifier for the contract.
  2. Party involved Identification Number: A unique identification number for the party involved.
  3. Contract Type: The type of contract (e.g. sales, service, employment).
  4. Start Date: The date on which the contract becomes valid.
  5. End Date: The date on which the contract expires (if applicable).
  6. Status: The current status of the contract (draft, active, expired, terminated, etc.)

A typical ‘party involved’ has the following attributes:

  1. Party involved Identification Number
  2. Party involved Name: It refers to the given name of a person or entity, or a label by which they are addressed or identified.

entry.title: SAPUI5 Rich Text Editor Custom File & Image Upload Handler
entry.content:
Introduction

If you’ve ever built a comments, notes, approvals, or collaboration feature in SAPUI5 using sap.ui.richtexteditor.RichTextEditor, you’ve probably faced this problem:

  • Users paste screenshots or images
  • TinyMCE embeds them as base64 blobs
  • Database size, payloads, and performance quickly degrade

Additionally, there is no native support for attaching documents such as PDFs or Excel files in a clean, enterprise-friendly way.

In real-world SAP applications, we usually want:

  • Images stored in the backend and referenced via URLs
  • Documents uploaded separately and inserted as download links
  • Automatic cleanup of unused images and attachments
  • Lightweight and performant HTML stored in the database

This blog explains a production-ready approach to extending SAPUI5 RichTextEditor (TinyMCE 7) to achieve exactly that.

What We’ll Build

By the end of this guide, your RichTextEditor will be able to:

  • Convert pasted or inserted images from base64 → backend URLs
  • Upload non-image files (PDF, DOCX, XLS, etc.)
  • Insert attachments as downloadable links at the cursor position
  • Automatically clean up orphaned images and files on save

All of this using:

  • TinyMCE hooks via beforeEditorInit

  • SAPUI5 + TypeScript

  • OData V4 entities (Comment, Image, Attachment)

High-Level Architecture

At a conceptual level, we separate responsibilities clearly:

  • Comment – Stores the rich text HTML content
  • Image – Stores image metadata and binary stream
  • Attachment – Stores document metadata and binary stream

The RichTextEditor stores only URLs, never raw binary data.

Note on Backend Entity Design

Important: The Comment, Image, and Attachment entities shown in this blog are purely illustrative and created only for demonstration purposes.

You are free to structure, merge, or normalize these entities based on your own domain model, security requirements, or performance considerations. The concepts demonstrated remain the same.

RichTextEditor Initialization (View & Controller)

RichTextEditor Setup in the View

The editor is configured to use TinyMCE 7 with a custom toolbar and an additional file upload button. Visibility is controlled via an Edit/Display mode flag.

<ri:RichTextEditor
  id="idContentRichTextEditor"
  editable="true"
  width="100%"
  height="90%"
  editorType="TinyMCE7"
  showGroupFont="true"
  showGroupLink="true"
  showGroupInsert="false"
  showGroupUndo="true"
  showGroupClipboard="false"
  showGroupStructure="true"
  customToolbar="true"
  visible="{= ${/mode} === 'Edit'}">

  <ri:customButtons>
    <Button
      id="idUploadFileButton"
      text="Upload File"
      icon="sap-icon://attachment"
      press="onUploadFileButtonPress"/>
  </ri:customButtons>

</ri:RichTextEditor>
<!-- Hidden file input for image upload -->
<core:HTML content="<input type='file' id='hiddenFileInput' accept='.doc,.docx,.xls,.xlsx,.pdf ' style='display:none;'/>" />

Runtime Initialization in onAfterRendering

The editor lifecycle is initialized in onAfterRendering to ensure that:

  • The view model is initialized
  • TinyMCE hooks are attached only once
  • A backend Comment entity exists before uploads begin
public async onAfterRendering(): Promise<void> {

  const oModel = new JSONModel({
    mode: 'Edit',
    content: ''
  });
  this.getView().setModel(oModel);

  this.getView()
    .byId('idContentRichTextEditor')
    .attachEventOnce(
      'beforeEditorInit',
      this.onBeforeEditorInit.bind(this)
    );

  const response = await fetch('/odata/v4/editor/Comment', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify({ content: 'Initial comment' })
  });

  if (response.ok) {
    const result = await response.json();
    this.commentId = result.ID;
    await this.loadCommentContent();
  } else {
    console.error('Failed to create comment');
  }
}

Injecting TinyMCE Configuration

SAPUI5 allows us to hook into TinyMCE initialization using beforeEditorInit. This is the key extension point.

Here, we:

  • Enable image paste support
  • Disable automatic base64 uploads
  • Inject a custom image upload handler
private onBeforeEditorInit(oEvent: Event): void {
  const params: any = (oEvent as any).getParameters();

  params.settings = {
    plugins: 'link image paste',
    paste_data_images: true,
    automatic_uploads: false,
    images_upload_handler: async (blobInfo, success, failure) => {
      try {
        await this.handleImageUpload(blobInfo, success, failure);
      } catch (e: any) {
        failure(e?.message || 'Upload failed');
      }
    }
  };
}

Handling Image Uploads (Replacing Base64)

When a user pastes an image:

  1. TinyMCE gives us the image as a Blob

  2. We create a backend Image entity

  3. Upload the binary stream

  4. Replace the base64 src with a relative backend URL using the success method handler.

 

private async handleImageUpload(
  blobInfo: any,
  success: (url: string) => void,
  failure: (err: string) => void
): Promise<void> {

  const blob = blobInfo.blob();
  const filename = blobInfo.filename();

  const metaRes = await fetch('/odata/v4/editor/Image', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify({
      fileName: filename,
      comment_ID: this.commentId
    })
  });

  if (!metaRes.ok) {
    failure('Meta create failed');
    return;
  }

  const meta = await metaRes.json();

  await fetch(`/odata/v4/editor/Image(${meta.ID})/imageData`, {
    method: 'PUT',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': blob.type || 'image/png' },
    body: blob
  });

  success(`/odata/v4/editor/Image(${meta.ID})/imageData`);
}

Uploading Attachments and Inserting Download Links

mages are only half the story. Enterprise users expect to attach documents.

We added a custom toolbar button to the RichTextEditor and a hidden <input type="file"> handles file selection.

Uploading Attachments

The attachment flow mirrors images:

  1. Create metadata

  2. Upload binary

  3. Insert a clickable link

 

 private onUploadFileButtonPress(): void {
    const hiddenInput = document.getElementById(
      'hiddenFileInput'
    ) as HTMLInputElement;
    if (hiddenInput) {
      // Update accept attribute to include more file types
      hiddenInput.accept =
        '.doc,.docx,.xls,.xlsx,.pdf,.txt,.png,.jpg,.jpeg,.gif';

      hiddenInput.onchange = (event: any) => {
        const files = event.target.files;
        if (files && files.length > 0) {
          this.handleAttachmentUpload(files[0]);
        }
        // Clear the input so the same file can be selected again
        hiddenInput.value = '';
      };
      hiddenInput.click();
    }
  }

  private async handleAttachmentUpload(file: File): Promise<void> {
    try {
      // First create the attachment record
      const response = await fetch('/odata/v4/editor/Attachment', {
        method: 'POST',
        body: JSON.stringify({
          fileName: file.name,
          fileSize: file.size,
          mimeType: file.type,
          comment_ID: this.commentId,
        }),
        headers: {
          'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        },
      });

      if (!response.ok) {
        console.error('Failed to create attachment record');
        return;
      }

      const result = await response.json();
      const attachmentId = result.ID;

      // Upload the actual file data
      const uploadResponse = await fetch(
        `/odata/v4/editor/Attachment(${attachmentId})/attachmentData`,
        {
          method: 'PUT',
          body: file,
          headers: {
            'Content-Type': file.type || 'application/octet-stream',
          },
        }
      );

      if (uploadResponse.ok) {
        const attachmentUrl = `/odata/v4/editor/Attachment(${attachmentId})/attachmentData`;

        // Insert anchor tag into the rich text editor
        this.insertAttachmentLink(file.name, attachmentUrl);
      } else {
        console.error('Attachment upload failed');
      }
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Attachment upload error:', error);
    }
  }

And then insert the link at the cursor position:

private insertAttachmentLink(fileName: string, attachmentUrl: string): void {
    const richTextEditor = this.getView().byId(
      'idContentRichTextEditor'
    ) as any;
    const nativeApi = richTextEditor.getNativeApi();

    if (nativeApi) {
      // Create the anchor tag HTML
      const anchorHtml = `<a href="${attachmentUrl}" download="${fileName}" target="_blank">${fileName}</a> `;

      nativeApi.execCommand('mceInsertContent', false, anchorHtml);
    }
  }

Now users get a clean, intuitive UX for documents.

Cleaning Up Orphaned Images and Attachments

One often-missed problem:
What happens when users remove images or links before saving?

Without cleanup, your backend fills up with unused binaries.

Solution:

  • Parse the HTML on save

  • Extract referenced IDs

  • Compare with DB

  • Delete unused records

private async onSaveButtonPress(): void {
    const richTextEditor = this.getView().byId(
      'idContentRichTextEditor'
    ) as any;
    const content = richTextEditor.getValue();

    // Extract IDs from current content
    const currentImageIds = this.extractImageSources(content);
    const currentAttachmentIds = this.extractAttachmentSources(content);

    try {
      // Get all images associated with this comment from database
      const imageResponse = await fetch(
        '/odata/v4/editor/Image?$filter=comment_ID%20eq%20%27' +
          this.commentId +
          '%27',
        {
          method: 'GET',
        }
      );

      let dbImageIds: string[] = [];
      if (imageResponse.ok) {
        const imageResult = await imageResponse.json();
        dbImageIds = imageResult.value.map((img: any) => img.ID);
      }

      // Get all attachments associated with this comment from database
      const attachmentResponse = await fetch(
        '/odata/v4/editor/Attachment?$filter=comment_ID%20eq%20%27' +
          this.commentId +
          '%27',
        {
          method: 'GET',
        }
      );

      let dbAttachmentIds: string[] = [];
      if (attachmentResponse.ok) {
        const attachmentResult = await attachmentResponse.json();
        dbAttachmentIds = attachmentResult.value.map((att: any) => att.ID);
      }

      // Find unused images (in DB but not in content)
      const unusedImageIds = dbImageIds.filter(
        (id) => !currentImageIds.includes(id)
      );

      // Find unused attachments (in DB but not in content)
      const unusedAttachmentIds = dbAttachmentIds.filter(
        (id) => !currentAttachmentIds.includes(id)
      );

      // Delete unused images
      for (const imageId of unusedImageIds) {
        try {
          const deleteResponse = await fetch(
            `/odata/v4/editor/Image(${imageId})`,
            {
              method: 'DELETE',
            }
          );
        } catch (error) {
          console.error(`Error deleting image ${imageId}:`, error);
        }
      }

      // Delete unused attachments
      for (const attachmentId of unusedAttachmentIds) {
        try {
          const deleteResponse = await fetch(
            `/odata/v4/editor/Attachment(${attachmentId})`,
            {
              method: 'DELETE',
            }
          );
        } catch (error) {
          console.error(`Error deleting attachment ${attachmentId}:`, error);
        }
      }

      // Save the comment content
      const saveResponse = await fetch(
        `/odata/v4/editor/Comment(${this.commentId})`,
        {
          method: 'PATCH',
          body: JSON.stringify({
            content: content,
          }),
          headers: {
            'Content-Type': 'application/json',
          },
        }
      );

      if (saveResponse.ok) {
        // Show success message to user
        const messageToast = await import('sap/m/MessageToast');
        messageToast.default.show('Comment saved successfully!');
      } else {
        console.error('Failed to save comment');

        // Show error message to user
        const messageToast = await import('sap/m/MessageToast');
        messageToast.default.show('Failed to save comment. Please try again.');
      }
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error during save process:', error);

      // Show error message to user
      const messageToast = await import('sap/m/MessageToast');
      messageToast.default.show(
        'An error occurred while saving. Please try again.'
      );
    }
  }

  // Add the missing extractAttachmentSources method
  private extractAttachmentSources(htmlContent: string): string[] {
    const hrefRegex = /<a[^>]+href="([^"]+)"[^>]*>/gi;
    const attachmentIds: string[] = [];
    let match;

    while ((match = hrefRegex.exec(htmlContent)) !== null) {
      const hrefUrl = match[1];

      // Extract ID from URL pattern: /odata/v4/editor/Attachment(ID)/attachmentData
      const idMatch = hrefUrl.match(
        /\/odata\/v4\/editor\/Attachment\(([^)]+)\)\/attachmentData/
      );

      if (idMatch && idMatch[1]) {
        attachmentIds.push(idMatch[1]);
      }
    }

    return attachmentIds;
  }

  private extractImageSources(htmlContent: string): string[] {
    const srcRegex = /<img[^>]+src="([^"]+)"/gi;
    const imageIds: string[] = [];
    let match;

    while ((match = srcRegex.exec(htmlContent)) !== null) {
      const srcUrl = match[1];

      // Extract ID from URL pattern: /odata/v4/editor/Image(ID)/imageData
      const idMatch = srcUrl.match(
        /\/odata\/v4\/editor\/Image\(([^)]+)\)\/imageData/
      );

      if (idMatch && idMatch[1]) {
        imageIds.push(idMatch[1]);
      }
    }

    return imageIds;
  }

Edit vs Display Mode

A common pattern is:

  • Edit mode – RichTextEditor
  • Display mode – core:HTML or FormattedText

Always sanitize HTML on the server side when rendering user-generated content.

Key Benefits of This Approach

  • No base64 blobs in your database
  • Faster load times and smaller payloads
  • Clean separation of content and binaries
  • Automatic lifecycle management
  • Enterprise-grade UX for documents and images

Optional Enhancements

You can easily extend this further:

  • Upload progress indicators

  • Drag & drop file support

  • Batch cleanup using OData $batch

  • Virus scanning or file-type validation

Conclusion

SAPUI5’s RichTextEditor combined with TinyMCE 7 is powerful—but only when extended correctly.

By leveraging TinyMCE hooks, custom upload handlers, and a simple OData-backed storage model, you can build a robust, scalable, and clean solution for handling pasted images and file attachments in SAPUI5 applications.

If you’re building any serious enterprise UI with rich text, this pattern is well worth adopting.

entry.title: Clean Core maturity and the new Extensibility Levels
entry.content:
For years, the architectural conversation around SAP S/4HANA seemed trapped in a rigid side.
On one side, the purist vision moving all development to side-by-side extensibility on SAP BTP. On the other side, the operational reality, where complex transactional logic and proximity to data made decoupling code technically expensive and sometimes unfeasible..

However, we often lost in this conversation: Clean Core... what's side-by-side... what's On-stack
Not so far back in time, we followed the 3-Tier Development Model. This framework tried to organize development into three tiers (Tier 1 for Cloud, Tier 2 with Wrappers, Tier 3 for Legacy).

While useful, there's a new pragmatic second generation framework: the Clean Core Level Concept
This new maturity model increases the availability of APIs and reduces the forced need for wrappers, incorporating classic ABAP use cases safely. But how does this translate into the modern architecture of Levels A, B, C, and D?

Level A: The Gold Standard (On-stack & Side-by-side)
Level A doesn't force you off-stack. It represents extensions that rely exclusively on stable, public interfaces backed by stability. Is agnostic to the deployment environment:

Side-by-side Extensions: Decoupled extensions running on the Business Technology Platform. This ecosystem allows for SAP Build (low-code/pro-code), CAP (Java/Node.js), and ABAP Cloud (Steampunk) to create scalable apps and automations

On-stack Extensions: Created inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud (either as Key User Extensions or Developer Extensions). This validates that building tightly coupled logic within the S/4HANA it's ok, provided that released technologies like RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming) and CDS Views are used. So that by using of released APIs and strict syntax checks, you can build tightly coupled logic (essential for transactional integrity) without creating technical debt

Level B: The Pragmatism of "Classic APIs"
Unlike Level A, which relies on stability contracts, Level B uses Classic APIs and frameworks. While not strictly "Cloud" capable, these are upgrade-stable.
You can identify these in the Cloudification Repository. Object frameworks such as SAPscript, and ALE/IDoc integrations fall into this category. This provides a critical "safe harbor," allowing to leverage proven legacy technologies without facing immediate refactoring pressure

Level C: Risk Management and Changelogs
When business reality demands the use of internal SAP objects for legacy scenarios, we enter Level C. Unlike the previous levels, there is an upgrade risk here. To mitigate it, SAP provides the Changelog for SAP Objects, a tool that allows you to identify incompatible changes early and plan proactive actions. Although not the preferred approach, it is a valid option if managed with wrappers to isolate the dependency.

Level D : The red line (Technical Debt)
Any extension that uses non-recommended patterns, such as direct modifications to the standard, direct writing to tables, or Implicit Enhancements, falls into this category. This represents the highest risk of technical debt and must be rigorously blocked using ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) checks. These patterns bypass standard logic and guarantee disruption during upgrades

Extensions objects are classified as unfit for customer use (marked as "noAPI" in the Cloudification Repository) 

By understanding Levels (A, B, C, D) we can make architectural decisions that balance technical purity with operational reality, prioritizing business stability and flexibility.... But Important!!: Beyond the levels, a Clean Core strategy requires governance. The fundamental principle is: Extensions must be avoided when possible. Before, we must to evaluate if standard functionality covers the process. If the extension is inevitable, we must ensure that extensions don't break Upgrades
To decide between an On-stack or Side-by-side implementation, customers should use the SAP Application Extension Methodology. This methodology helps to define a custom extension strategy. It addresses challenges like "clean core" by offering a structured, standard approach. This ensures a common understanding and terminology and it allows to assess technical options and make informed decisions to build an extension framework for your organization.
